DamEtel

I found it interesting that all three sides - patriots, loyalists, and passifists - of the American Revolution believed they were following God's will, using the Bible for support. Doesn't it make you wonder how valid the Bible is if God's word supports YES, NO, and NEITHER all at the same time?!?!?!

post_info.post_title: 3 contradictory sides all use same Bible as validation

maco
IMO, Jesus would go with "pacifist". Then again, that one part where it says to obey your country as you would God goes with loyalist...
DamEtel

The same thing applies to slavery: both the North and South used the Bible to support their contradictory positions.
 
 I remember reading somewhere that Lincoln - who always had problems with Christianity - had problems reconciling the Bible and the Civil War for this kind reason: how can both sides both use the Bible to justify their positions on slavery and other issues? Apparently, it never bothered him as much before because wars - like those of Protestant Reformation, the American Revolutionary War, the War of 1812, etc. - were between two or more different nations/religions. But in our Civil War it was a single nation, using the same religion, to support their directly contradictory positions.
nowherenear2003
Good point - I hadn't thought about it that way - both sides of the war were the same identical religion. So much for myth that all wars are the result of religious differences!
maco

Good point - I hadn't thought about it that way - both sides of the war were the same identical religion. So much for myth that all wars are the result of religious differences!

 But how would each side have justified their position if they couldn't point to the Bible? Without using the Bible as justification, they'd have either not had justification or made something up. Not every war starts because of religious differences, but it sure is justified through them.
Obvious Child

I found it interesting that all three sides - patriots, loyalists, and passifists - of the American Revolution believed they were following God's will, using the Bible for support. Doesn't it make you wonder how valid the Bible is if God's word supports YES, NO, and NEITHER all at the same time?!?!?!
Like how people fight against each other according to their conscience, and so we should ignore conscience? Or different sides all claim the American Constitution supports their position, from theocracy to enforced secularism to state non-participation in religion? Or different sides claim the scientific evidence supports ID, YEC and Darwin.
 
 People claim that they have support. Doesn't mean they do.
nowherenear2003

But how would each side have justified their position if they couldn't point to the Bible? Without using the Bible as justification, they'd have either not had justification or made something up. Not every war starts because of religious differences, but it sure is justified through them.

 
 I suppose people at war like to convince their opponent that God is on their side - if they believe in religion - but there have been plenty of wars in the last 100 years involving atheist states.
 
 Question - what is the common problem in all wars?

post_info.post_title: Question - what is the common problem in all wars?

johnhanks

Good point - I hadn't thought about it that way - both sides of the war were the same identical religion. So much for myth that all wars are the result of religious differences!

 
 I'm not familiar with that myth. Far more likely, I think, is that the vast majority of wars are fought over property, territory and power; where religion is invoked as casus belli, its role is to sanctify and paint over the real, somewhat baser motives.
 
 Just MHO, of course.

When something can be anything, that is as good as it meaning nothing.

 
 By this logic everything means nothing.
 
 Things CAN be used as anything, but that doesn't make it correct. I CAN say that 2+2=5 but that doesn't make it correct.
 
 They are only as good as the way they are used. If the bible is interpreted according to appropriate rules of hermaneutics, then it takes on a correct meaning.
